sub_topic: Applying the Fourier transform to signal processing
message_1: A signal $f(t)=\sin(2\pi 500 t)+0.5\sin(2\pi 1000 t)$ is transmitted over a cable. Use Fourier transform to determine the frequency components of the signal.
message_2:
To determine the frequency components of the signal, we can analyze the given function $f(t)$. The Fourier transform is used to convert a time-domain signal into its frequency-domain representation. However, in this case, we can directly identify the frequency components from the given function without computing the Fourier transform.

The function is given by:

$f(t) = \sin(2\pi 500 t) + 0.5\sin(2\pi 1000 t)$

The function consists of two sinusoidal components:

1. $\sin(2\pi 500 t)$: This component has a frequency of $500$ Hz, as it can be written as $\sin(2\pi f_1 t)$ with $f_1 = 500$ Hz.

2. $0.5\sin(2\pi 1000 t)$: This component has a frequency of $1000$ Hz, as it can be written as $0.5\sin(2\pi f_2 t)$ with $f_2 = 1000$ Hz.

So, the frequency components of the signal are $500$ Hz and $1000$ Hz.
